body.para: On Tue, 2009-01-13 at 13:29 -0500, Eric Butera wrote:

quote.quotepara: On Tue, Jan 13, 2009 at 1:14 PM, Jason Pruim <japruim@raoset.com> wrote:
On Jan 13, 2009, at 9:46 AM, Ashley Sheridan wrote:
On Tue, 2009-01-13 at 09:33 -0500, tedd wrote:
At 2:33 PM +0000 1/13/09, Ashley Sheridan wrote:
On Tue, 2009-01-13 at 09:20 -0500, tedd wrote:
Jason:
In addition to what everyone else has said, try this:
$self = basename($_SERVER['SCRIPT_NAME'])
I use it for forms -- you might find it useful.
Cheers,
tedd -- ------- http://sperling.com http://ancientstones.com http://earthstones.com
No need to use it on forms, as leaving the action attribute empty means the form sends to itself anyway.
Ash:
That's what I've said for years, but (I think it was on this list, but too lazy to look) there was a concern that some browsers may not follow that default behavior.
However, using what I provided will work regardless.
Cheers,
------- http://sperling.com http://ancientstones.com http://earthstones.com
I've not yet seen a browser that doesn't do this, and it's pretty old HTML really, so I don't see a reason why any new browsers wouldn't incorporate it.
I prefer to be specific in my programming :)
echo <<<HTML <form method="post" action="{$self}"> ...

</form>
HTML;
?>
But to each his (Or her) own right?
You know that's asking for xss, right?

body.para: How would you go about XSS on this? As I see it, you'd need register_globals on for that to work.
